div.p: PROCEEDINGS OF A GENERAL COURT MARTIAL, HELD AT PHILADELPHIA, IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA, BY ORDER OF HIS EXCELLENCY GENERAL WASHINGTON, COMMANDER IN CHIEF OF THE ARMY OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, FOR THE TRIAL OF MAJOR GENERAL HOWE, DECEMBER 7, 1781. Major General Baron STEUBEN, Pre≈øident.
PHILADELPHIA: PRINTED BY HALL AND SELLERS, IN MARKET-STREET. M,DCC,LXXXII.

div.head: PROCEEDINGS OF A GENERAL COURT MARTIAL, &c.
div.p: Major General Baron STEUBEN, PRESIDENT.
Captain WALKER, acting as JUDGE ADVOCATE.
THE Pre≈øident, Members and Judge Advocate being ≈øworn, the Judge Advocate produced the papers No. 1 and 2, which, together with the General Orders for a≈ø≈øembling the Court, were read as follows:

div.head: (No. 1.) STATE OF GEORGIA. IN ASSEMBLY, January 17, 1780.
div.p: THE Committee appointed to take into con≈øideration the ≈øituation of the State ≈øince the 29th day of December, 1778, report, That the capital and troops in this State were ≈øacrificed on the ≈øaid 29th of December, which was the fir≈øt cau≈øe of the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes and con≈øequences which en≈øued.

Your Committee are of opinion, that the Delegates of this State ≈øhould be directed to promote a trial of Major General Howe, who commanded on that day. They find that the good people of this State were further di≈øcouraged, by the ≈øaid Major General Howe cro≈ø≈øing the Savanna river next day with the troops that e≈øcaped from Savanna, and ordering tho≈øe at Sunbury and Augu≈øta to do the ≈øame, leaving this State at the mercy of the enemy without any continental troops, in≈øtead of retreating to the back country and gathering the inhabitants. The country, thus abandoned, became an ea≈øy prey to the Briti≈øh troops, they marching up and taking po≈øt at Augu≈øta, and ≈øending detachments to every part of the State.

closer.signed: Extract from the Minutes, GEORGE SEIGAR, C. G. A.

div.head: (No. 2.) BY THE UNITED STATES IN CONGRESS ASSEMBLED, September 5, 1781.
div.p: THE Report of the Committee, to whom were referred the in≈øtructions from the A≈ø≈øembly of the State of Georgia to the Delegates of that State, and their motion thereon, relative to Major General Robert Howe, was taken into con≈øideration; and thereupon

Ordered, That the extract from the Minutes of the General A≈ø≈øembly of the State of Georgia, re≈øpecting the conduct of Major General Howe in his command of the troops in the ≈øaid State in December 1778, be tran≈ømitted to the Commander in Chief, and that he be directed to cau≈øe as enquiry to be made into the matters therein alledged, in ≈øuch manner as he ≈øhall judge proper, as ≈øoon as circum≈øtances will admit.

closer.signed: Extract from the Minutes, (Signed) CHARLES THOMSON, Secretary.

div.head: GENERAL ORDERS.
div.p: A GENERAL Court-Martial will a≈ø≈øemble at ten o'clock to-morrow morning, at the City Tavern, for the trial of Major General Howe on the following charges, exhibited again≈øt him by the Delegates of the State of Georgia in Congre≈øs, by order of the General A≈ø≈øembly of the ≈øaid State.

1≈øt. For ≈øacrificing by his conduct the capital of the State of Georgia, and the troops of that State, on the 29th day of December, 1778, which was the fir≈øt cau≈øe of the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes and con≈øequences which en≈øued.

2dly. For cro≈ø≈øing the Savanna river the day ≈øucceeding the 29th December, 1778, with the troops that e≈øcaped from Savanna, and ordering tho≈øe at Sunbury and Augu≈øta to do the ≈øame, leaving the State at the mercy of the enemy without any continental troops, in≈øtead of retreating to the back country and gathering the inhabitants; whereby the good people of the State were further di≈øcouraged, and the country, thus abandoned, became an ea≈øy prey to the Briti≈øh troops, they marching up and taking po≈øt at Augu≈øta, and ≈øending detachments to every part of the State.
Major General HOWE appears before the Court, and the above charges being read to him, he pleads
To the fir≈øt charge‚ÄîNOT GUILTY.

To the ≈øecond charge‚Äîhe acknowledges that he cro≈ø≈øed the Savanna river after he retreated, as ≈øoon as circum≈øtances would admit, and that he ordered the garri≈øon at Sunbury to evacuate that po≈øt, and join him wherever he might be; but does not recollect that he ordered the evacuation of Augu≈øta.
The evidence in ≈øupport of the charges not attending, the Court adjourned till to-morrow morning, ten o'clock.

div.head: DECEMBER 8th.
div.p: The Court being met according to adjournment, the Judge Advocate informs the Court, that two material witne≈ø≈øes in ≈øupport of the charges are General Elbert and Colonel Walton; that the former is in Maryland, and he is informed was ≈øome time ≈øince ≈øummoned by the Board of War; that, however, he is not arrived, and that Colonel Walton refu≈øes to attend, for rea≈øons alledged in his letter annexed, No. 3. Whereupon the Court ordered the letter No. 4, annexed hereto, to be written to the Delegates of the State of Georgia; and then the Court adjourned till Monday morning, ten o'clock.

body.head: (No. 3.)
body.p: I HAVE had the favor of your ≈øummons to attend a Court-Martial, appointed by his Excellency the Commander in Chief to ≈øit on the conduct of Major General Howe, on the complaint of the State of Georgia. It is not unknown to Major General Howe, or to the Delegates of the State, that I declined to give evidence upon this ≈øubject whil≈øt the pro≈øecution was in the form of an enquiry, and depo≈øitions taking in the War-Office by order of Congre≈øs, until mea≈øures ≈øhould be taken for obtaining the te≈øtimony of Major General Elbert, who commanded the Georgia brigade of continental troops on the 29th day of December, 1778, the corps which ≈øuffered the mo≈øt by capture on that occa≈øion: And the ≈øacrifice or lo≈øs of the troops being the principal object of the pro≈øecution, I ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe that the trial would be partial without his evidence; or, at lea≈øt, that implied cen≈øure might be recorded again≈øt his conduct in the minutes of the Court, which might injure a mo≈øt valuable citizen and ≈øoldier of the State. Indeed, I ≈øhould think my≈øelf acce≈ø≈øary in the wrong which might take place, did I not plead that the trial might be fait and full, taking in his e≈ø≈øential evidence. For the≈øe rea≈øons, Sir, it is that I have hitherto and do now declined to attend the Court; but when it ≈øhall be decided to take General Elbert's te≈øtimony before the proceedings are clo≈øe, then ≈øhall I chearfully depo≈øe what I know in this ca≈øe. I beg that you would plea≈øe to make my re≈øpects to the Court, and acquaint the members with the rea≈øons a≈ø≈øigned for my conduct.

postscript.p: P. S. I have under≈øtood that General Elbert, who is in Maryland, was ≈øent for by the late Commi≈ø≈øioners of the War-Office; but I do not know it as a fact.

body.trailer: To Major BENJAMIN WALKER, Judge Advocate, &c.

body.head: (No. 4.)
body.p: THE Court-Martial ordered by his Excellency the Commander in Chief for the trial of Major General Howe, upon certain charges exhibited again≈øt him by the Delegates of the State of Georgia, having met and ≈øummoned the evidences who≈øe names were given in, are acquainted that only Colonel Walton can be found, and that he declines to give his evidence, for the rea≈øons contained in his letter which is inclo≈øed; that General Elbert and Colonel Marbury are in Maryland, and tho' ≈øummoned ≈øome time ≈øince to attend, as the Court are informed, are not yet arrived.‚ÄîThe Court therefore reque≈øt, Gentlemen, to know whether you are content the trial ≈øhould proceed upon ≈øuch evidence as can now be obtained, or whether you expect the trial to be po≈øtponed to a di≈øtant day, when the deficient evidence may be procured. I am, Gentlemen,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt obedient, STEUBEN, Major General, Pre≈øident.

div.head: DECEMBER 10th.
div.p: The Court met according to adjournment, and the Judge Advocate read to them a letter from the Delegates of the State of Georgia (No. 5) in an≈øwer to their's of Saturday; Whereupon the Court determined to proceed to the examination of ≈øuch evidences as could be procured, and in the mean time mea≈øures ≈øhould be taken to procure the ab≈øent evidences.

body.head: (No. 5.)
body.p: WE do our≈øelves the plea≈øure to reply to your letter of ye≈øterday, and are ≈øorry to under≈øtand that the operative powers of the Court are impeded for want of evidence in the ca≈øe of Major General Howe, on the part of the State of Georgia. We are not informed by the Board of War with the time or conveyance of the ≈øummon≈øes ≈øent to General Elbert and Colonel Marbury; and it will appear pretty evident to you, that we have no coercive powers to compel evidence to attend. Under a train of circum≈øtances peculiar in them≈øelves, we cannot pre≈øume to dictate to the Court; but if difficulties exi≈øt, the propriety of a reference to Congre≈øs will readily occur. We annex the names of ≈øuch per≈øons as have occurred to us ≈øince the delivery of tho≈øe to the Board of War, who≈øe evidence we wi≈øh to have taken on the trial, in addition to the former. We are, Sir,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt humble Servants, EDWARD TELFAIR, W. JONES.

body.trailer: Colonel Tenant, Major Lucas, Captain Gla≈øcock, Major Porter, and Mr. John Gibbons, all of whom are in this city.
The Hon. Major General STEUBEN, Pre≈øident, &c.

div.p: The Court adjourned till Friday morning, ten o'clock.

div.head: DECEMBER 14th.
div.p: The Court met according to adjournment.
Major Lucas was ≈øworn.
Q. by the Court. Were you in the army in Georgia under the orders of General Howe the latter end of 1778, when the enemy invaded that State?
A. I was.
Q. In what capacity did you act?
A. As a Captain in the Georgia Line.
Q. Do you know what ≈øteps were taken by General Howe to prevent the enemy's landing in that State?
A. I vi≈øited the po≈øt at Girardeau's landing, where Captain Smith was po≈øted with about 75 men; my ≈øituation in the army prevented me from ≈øeeing the different po≈øts.
Q. Where did the enemy land?
A. At Girardeau's landing.
Q. Do you know the oppo≈øition that was made to their landing?
A. No; I heard a firing, but was not pre≈øent.
Q Where was the main body of the army when the enemy landed, and at what di≈øtance was it from the place of landing?
A. At Fair-Lawn, better than a mile from the place of landing.
Q. Do you know what force they landed?
A. No; I under≈øtood, when I was pri≈øoner, that they landed 2500 men at that place.
Q. Did they land at any other place?
A. Not to my knowledge.
Q. Where were you po≈øted that day?
A. With my regiment in the Georgia brigade, on the left of the line.
Q. After the enemy had landed, did the line move down to oppo≈øe them, or did they wait the enemy's attack?
A. They waited the enemy's attack.
Q. Did the enemy attack them in their po≈øition at Fair-Lawn, and what re≈øi≈øtance was made?

A. We were po≈øted in a po≈øition of defence again≈øt the enemy, the South-Carolina brigade on the right, the Georgia brigade on the left, the artillery in the centre, and a party of militia, under the command of Colonel Walton, on the right of the whole, to oppo≈øe the enemy at a pa≈øs, I think a mile from the main body, where the enemy's infantry did attack them; but a ≈ømall re≈øi≈øtance being made by them, enabled the enemy's infantry to attack our right flanks immediately after, at which time the main body moved on, firing a few ≈øhot from their artillery, which did ≈øome ≈ømall damage in the Georgia brigade; about that time we had orders to retreat, agreeable to the di≈øpo≈øition given the night before, which was by a defile called Springhill to M'Gilvray's gate, an advantageous piece of ground.
Q. Was the retreat conducted agreeably to the di≈øpo≈øition?

A. No; the brigade I belonged to moved off in column, and were afterwards ordered by the commanding officer to form by files, and ≈øome time afterwards they broke, and the principal part went into Savanna. Two parties were taken out of the brigade, by order of General Howe, as we were moving in column, to act as infantry on the flanks; the piece of artillery ordered to cover the rear of that brigade quitted its ≈øtation, and left the brigade ≈øhortly after the retreat began.
Q. By who≈øe orders did the party go into town?
A. I cannot tell.
Q. Was the commanding officer with them?

A. I cannot ≈øay; I being in the front of the brigade moved on; the troops being formed in files, they extended to a great length. Some time after the troops were formed in files, Colonel Elbert left us, as I under≈øtood afterwards, to look for a pa≈øs over M'Gilvray's creek. I arrived at the mouth of the creek with about eighty of the front of the column; for want of orders I ≈øtaid ≈øome time there, when a ≈øuperior officer hoi≈øted the flag, and ≈øurrendered the party.
Q. Who was the officer that ≈øurrendered the party?
A. Major John Haber≈øham.
Q. What number did your brigade con≈øi≈øt of?
A. I can't certainly tell, I believe upwards of 300.
Q. Were only the eighty men you mention, who arrived with you at the creek, included in the ≈øurrender of Major Haber≈øham?
A. The greater part of tho≈øe who went into town had by that time arrived at the creek, and were included in the ≈øurrender.
Q. To what number of troops did Major Haber≈øham ≈øurrender?
A. The greate≈øt part of the enemy's army had by that time arrived.
Q. Did you ≈øee Colonel Elbert, after he left you to look for the pa≈øs?
A. No.
Q. As you were the head of the brigade, what occa≈øioned the brigade to leave the line of march, pointed out in the di≈øpo≈øition:
A. Colonel Elbert was at the head of the brigade, when they left the route pointed out in orders.
Q. Did you, from the time you took up the line of march, until the time you left the route laid down in the di≈øpo≈øition, ≈øee General Howe, or either of his Aids, with Colonel Elbert?
A. No.
Q. When your brigade left the route, was the front of it at its proper di≈øtance in the general column?
A. The brigade had halted to form by files; this had occa≈øioned the brigade to fall about 3 or 400 yards in the rear of the artillery.
Q. Had General Elbert been ab≈øent from the column from the time you took up the line of march, till you left the route laid down in the di≈øpo≈øition?
A. No.
Q. Was the march by files a part of the general di≈øpo≈øition given out?
A. No.
Q. What time did the firing commence at the landing?
A. About ≈øun-ri≈øe.
Q. by General Howe. Where was the Georgia brigade ordered to break into files?
A. Nigh the burying-ground.
Q. Were there ≈øome roads which led into Savanna not far from the burying-ground?
A. Yes.
Q. Did you ≈øee me at that place?
A. No; I ≈øaw you a little time before pa≈øs the brigade.
Q. Did you hear me ≈øpeak to the officers and men as I pa≈ø≈øed the brigade?
A. I do not recollect it.
Q. Were the men in good order when I pa≈ø≈øed them?
A. Yes.
Q. Did you hear me, in general terms, commend the order the troops were in?
A. I think I did.
Q. Do you know of any troops employed to break up the ground in front of the line?
A. Detachments were ≈øent out the night before the action for that and other purpo≈øes.
Q. What part of the town did the troops break into?
A. About the centre.
Q. Was the part of the ≈øwamp, where the enemy cro≈ø≈øed to attack the militia on the right, commonly known to be pa≈ø≈øable?
A. I had always under≈øtood it was impa≈ø≈øable.
Q. by the Court. What time did the firing commence on the right with the militia, under Colonel Walton?
A. I can't exactly tell; about two o'clock.
Q. What mea≈øures were taken to prevent the enemy's advance from the landing, and what oppo≈øition was made?
A. Several detachments went from the line after the enemy had landed; I do not know for what purpo≈øe.
Q. by General Howe. Are you acquainted with the ≈øituation of Girardeau's plantation?
A. I have been there frequently, but am not perfectly acquainted with its ≈øituation.
Q. Is there a large extent of rice-fields before it, and are tho≈øe fields perfectly level?
A. There is an exten≈øive plain of rice-fields before it.
Q. How wide do you think it is from Girardeau's hou≈øe to the landing-place?
A. I can't really ≈øay; I ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe about three quarters or a mile.
Q. Are there any cau≈øeways through that rice-field?
A. There are a great number of banks pa≈ø≈øable.
Q. Were you ever in the rice-field?
A. Yes.
Q. What nature of ground is the field in general?
A. Wet at times, but pa≈ø≈øable for infantry.
Q. When the retreat was ordered, what was the order of march directed?
A. In one column.
Q. Did they move off in that order?
A. Yes.
Q. by Court. Was the road through which the column marched practicable for a larger front than a file?
A. Yes; large enough for any platoon.
Q by General Howe. Did the troops keep in good order while they remained in column?
A. They were in perfect good order whil≈øt in column.
Q. When you arrived at the creek, did you attempt to pa≈øs it?
A. No.
Q. Do you know of any action between our troops and the enemy at Springhill defile?
A. I was not there; I heard a firing, which I ≈øuppo≈øed to be there.
Q. Where were you then?
A. Near M'Gilvray's creek.
The Court adjourned till to-morrow morning, ten o'clock.

div.head: DECEMBER 15th.
div.p: The Court met according to adjournment.
Nicholas White produced to the Court a general order, appointing him to act as Judge Advocate, vice Captain Walker, who≈øe indi≈øpo≈øition obliged him to retire, after which he was ≈øworn.
Major Lucas's te≈øtimony continued.
Q. by General Howe. Why did you not pa≈øs the creek?
A. For want of orders.
Q. Did you hear from the enemy, when a pri≈øoner, by what means they di≈øcovered the pa≈øs on my right?
A. I heard, when among them, it reported, that a Negroe had di≈øcovered to the commanding officer the defile by which they pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øwamp.
Q. by Court. Whether, from your knowledge of the rice-fields near Mr. Girardeau's hou≈øe, was it ea≈øy to overflow them with water?
A. I cannot tell.
Q. by General Howe. Could you have cro≈ø≈øed the creek with your party, had you been ordered to do it?

A. I could have cro≈ø≈øed my≈øelf by ≈øwimming, and ≈øuch of my party as could ≈øwim, with the lo≈øs of our arms and accoutrements. On my arrival at the creek I met with Captain Day, of the Georgia line, who was then taking off his boots on purpo≈øe to cro≈øs the creek; I a≈øked him if he had ≈øeen the commanding officer; he ≈øaid he had not, but that I was his commanding officer, and would act as I thought proper; on which he put on his boots and joined me.
Q. Was it before, or upon the retreat, that the damage was done to the Georgia brigade by the enemy's artillery?
A. Upon the retreat.
The Court adjourned to Thur≈øday morning, ten o'clock.

Mr. John Wereat being under a nece≈ø≈øity of leaving the city of Philadelphia, the Judge Advocate, on behalf of the pro≈øecution, and Major General Howe in his own right, and by direction of the General Court-Martial, agreed to take his depo≈øition before one of the Ju≈øtices of the Peace for the city of Philadelphia. The Judge Advocate having a≈øked Mr. Wereat the different que≈øtions propo≈øed by the Delegates of the State of Georgia, and he an≈øwering them in the negative, being a private citizen, the Judge Advocate did not think it nece≈ø≈øary to a≈øk Mr. Wereat any further que≈øtions on behalf of the pro≈øecution. Then the following que≈øtions were put by General Howe:
Q. Do you recollect that the inhabitants of the town were advi≈øed by me to remove their effects, for fear of accident?

A. I believe it was hinted to the inhabitants to provide again≈øt the wor≈øt by removing their effects; that many did remove part of their property, and more would have done ≈øo, could they have procured boats and carriages for that purpo≈øe.
Q. Do you know the mora≈øs below Tatnall's gate, in front of the po≈øition of the troops on the 29th of December, and the ground on the other ≈øide of it?

A. I am well acquainted with the road leading from Savanna by Tatnall's to the place where the enemy landed. Some di≈øtance below Tatnall's gate there is a cau≈øeway through a mora≈øs, or very boggy ≈øwamp, which I believe is not pa≈ø≈øable for a footman above the cau≈øeway, and but with difficulty below it.
Q. Are you acquainted with that part of the ≈øwamp where the enemy pa≈ø≈øed on my right, and if you are, plea≈øe to de≈øcribe it?

A. I knew nothing of the ≈øwamp by which the enemy pa≈ø≈øed at that time, but have been through it frequently ≈øince. It was not wide, but a thicket, and boggy. The French, at the ≈øiege of Savanna, made it pa≈ø≈øable, by laying poles acro≈øs it.
Q. What are the landing places above and below my po≈øition at Fair-Lawn, and is there any approach by Haner's mill, and if there is, where does it come into the town?

A. There were a variety of landing-places, both above and below the place of the enemy's landing at Girardeau's; namely, Co≈øtin's Bluff, Half-moon Bluff, Mulbryne's and Thunderbolt, below, the former called three, and the latter five miles from Savanna by land, and may be ≈øomething more. Above, and by way of the Back river, there are Rae's and M'Gilvray's landings, the former five, and the latter two miles by land from Savanna, and five intermediate landing-places between them. All the≈øe landings, both above and below, are on high land, with roads leading from them towards Savanna. There is a road that goes round near Haner's mill, and comes in by the barracks. It was a very good one in September and October 1779.

Q. by the Court. Were you in the American army in Georgia, at the time the Briti≈øh troops under the command of Colonel Campbell invaded that State?

A. Q. Do you know how long, previous to the inva≈øion of Georgia, General Howe received intelligence of the de≈øigns of the enemy, and what ≈øteps were taken by him in con≈øequence?

A. A. In the year 1773, Government ordered a return of the men to be made from the age of 16 to 60, as I recollect, and by that return it appears that there were two thou≈øand five or ≈øix hundred men, the preci≈øe number I do not recollect. Since that return was made, there was a con≈øiderable augmentation of inhabitants to the we≈øtward, but I do not believe they made up for the number of fugitive tories that ≈øought protection from the enemy from the lower country. So that I ≈øuppo≈øe that at that day the number of fighting men might be nearly equal with that returned in 1773, or not ≈øo much.
Q. When the inva≈øion of Georgia took place, what proportion of militia was reque≈øted by General Howe of the executive authority?
A. I do not know.

A. The pro≈øpect of lo≈øing the town and the neighbouring country, I believe, prevented many from joining the army, they being employed in removing their families and property from the more ≈øouthern parts, except about Sunbury, as well as in the neighbourhood of Savanna; and whether tho≈øe from the we≈øtward had been called for in tim I do not know, but there were a very ≈ømall proportion in ≈øervice upon that occa≈øion. What number were in arms with the corps at Sunbury I do not know. I had under my command at Savanna, including infantry, artillery and the company of hor≈øe, which I did not include in my former e≈øtimation, ≈øomething above 100 men; the preci≈øe number I cannot a≈øcertain. I believe another cau≈øe why the militia was backward upon that occa≈øion was, the di≈øputes already ≈øugge≈øted between the Governor and General.
Q. Was the army provided with tools to erect the works propo≈øed at Girardeau's Bluff?
A. I do not know.
Q. You mention your party being in confu≈øion at the time you were ordered to attack the Briti≈øh light infantry. What was the occa≈øion of that confu≈øion?
A. The ≈øuperior numbers of the enemy who were drawn up in front.
Q. Do you know of any previous di≈øpo≈øitions made by General Howe in ca≈øe of retreat?
A. I do not, I never received any orders to retreat.
Q. Did you ≈øee the General's orders i≈ø≈øued previous to the affair of the 29th?
A. I did not; the only general order I ≈øaw was that putting the militia in general orders „Äà‚óä„Äâ continental command, to the be≈øt of my recollection.
Q. How far is Milledge's pa≈øs from the po≈øt then occupied by the main body of General Howe's army?

A. I have already ≈øaid that the head of the ≈øecond branch was about a mile di≈øtant from town, and from thence about half a mile to the pa≈øs; ≈øo that the pa≈øs being about a mile and an half from town, in the circuit of the path, and the po≈øition of General Howe's main body being below the town, the circuit would be continued about one quarter of a mile farther; therefore, to the be≈øt of my judgment, the di≈øtance was about one mile and three quarters.
Q. What was the general face of the country over which the enemy pa≈ø≈øed to make their attack?

A. In the front of the American line lay a bed or row of ≈øprings, which formed to the le≈øt a gut extending to the river, whil≈øt tho≈øe which lay more to the right make a mar≈øh in the oppo≈øite direction. Immediately below Tatnall's fence, it a≈ø≈øumes the appearance of a ≈øwamp (by which I mean low, watry and miry ground, largely wooded and thickly underbru≈øhed.) At the commencement of this ≈øwamp, that is a little below Tatnall's fence, was the ≈ømall work which the General had cau≈øed to be thrown up on his right, and which, by his de≈øire, I examined. To the right of that work, about half a mile, to the be≈øt of my judgment, though I never traver≈øed it in a direct line, is the pa≈øs acro≈øs the ≈øwamp to Milledge's old field. The dull way or path which leads from town to this pa≈øs begins its cour≈øe about oppo≈øite the burying-ground, and continues in a ≈øouthern direction until it gains the head of a ≈øecond mar≈øhy branch, about one mile di≈øtant from town, to the be≈øt of my judgment. It then turns down that branch in a north-ea≈øt direction to the pa≈øs, in di≈øtance about half a mile, to the be≈øt of my judgment. From the other, or ea≈øtern ≈øide, to the Governor's gate, is about three quarters of a mile, or not quite ≈øo much, at which place the path u≈øed to enter the great road; but latterly, and before that day, mo≈øt of the old fields, and all the ground lying between that and the gate, had been enclo≈øed and under cultivation. At this cro≈ø≈øing-place, the waters appear to me to have forced them≈øelves into a ≈øingle bed, and to form a kind of running branch of creek, over which there appears to have been once a wooden bridge; but ≈øince my remembrance, there were only two or three ≈øleepers or logs acro≈øs. On my way from reporting to the General, and before I got quite up to my command, Colonel William M'Into≈øh, who commanded the hor≈øe that day, cried out that the enemy were cro≈ø≈øing the branch, which I that moment perceived. It was the branch neare≈øt to town, and the place they cro≈ø≈øed ≈øome little di≈øtance below the path-way, ≈øay about 100 or 150 yards. I take it, they ≈øtept over upon roots and high tufts, which are common in the mar≈øhy branches of that country. Upon their cro≈ø≈øing this branch, I neither went or ≈øent to the General, becau≈øe, from the intelligence I had already given, it was an event he mu≈øt have expected, and that it would have been pre≈øently announced by firing.
Q Did you ever mention to General Howe Milledge's pa≈øs previous to the day of action?

A. I do not remember to have mentioned it to him until the time I have already mentioned. The fir≈øt object was to guard again≈øt the enemy's landing, which occupied my mind; and after they had landed at Girardeau's, I was not with the General until the time I have mentioned, as I recollect. When I went down, in the anxiety I have heretofore related, the fir≈øt enquiry was re≈øpecting that pa≈øs.
Q. What were the rea≈øons that prevented your ≈øeeing the general orders on the day of attack?
A. I know of no particular rea≈øon; the militia had but lately been put under continental command, and I was not in the practice of going for orders, nor were they ≈øent to me.
Q. Whether the ≈øhores above Nunez's creek were equally practicable for the enemy to land as tho≈øe below?

A. The ≈øhores or bluffs above Nunez's creek are not ≈øo ≈øteep and abrupt as the hill at Girardeau's; but the navigation to them is much more difficult. Mu≈øgrove's or Nunez's creek was more difficult to cro≈øs by an enemy, than the ob≈øtruction below the town.
The Court adjourned till to-morrow morning, ten o'clock.

div.head: JANUARY 9th.
div.p: The Court met agreeable to adjournment.
Colonel Walton's te≈øtimony continued.
Q. Was the town of Savanna fortified in any degree?

At the north-ea≈øt point of the Tru≈øtees gardens, a fort had been ≈øome con≈øiderable time before erected, and ≈øome pieces of 18 pound cannon and others of le≈øs ≈øize planted in it, for the evident defence of the town. I do not recollect any other works, except tho≈øe ≈ølightly thrown up in the field upon that occa≈øion.
Q. When General Howe gave a≈ø≈øurance of defending the town, did you under≈øtand from him upon what principles he meant to defend it?

A. I do not know the principles upon which the defence of the town was undertaken, in any military point of view. I heard General Howe ≈øay, in pre≈øence of a number of the inhabitants of the town, on the 23th or 26th preceding the attack, I forget which, that the enemy's army was compo≈øed of raw boys from the Highlands and of Delancey's green-coats, who would not fight, and that he did not care if they were double the number.

Q. Did you proceed with Dr. Hall to South-Carolina, agreeable to the re≈øolution of the Governor and Council.

A. Yes.

A. I remember that the militia under my command did duty upon the hill at Ogechee with the continental troops under the command of Major General Howe, and I believe when they returned the army was left upon that ground.
Q. After the report ≈øuppo≈øed to be from a de≈øerter, was a body of Carolina militia, under the command of Colonel Bull, marched to Savanna?
A. I remember that Colonel Bull came over into Georgia with a body of South-Carolina militia; but I do not recollect the particular time, or upon who≈øe application they came over.

div.head: JANUARY 10th.
div.p: The Court met agreeable to adjournment.

Q. Were you in the army in Georgia, at the time the Briti≈øh troops under the command of Colonel Campbell invaded that State?
A. I was.
Q. In what capacity did you act?

A. As a Major in the Georgia line previous to the inva≈øion, and on the 29th of December acted as a volunteer Aid with General Howe, having re≈øigned my commi≈ø≈øion in the line five or ≈øix weeks before.
Q. What ≈øteps were taken by General Howe to prevent the enemy landing?

A. The troops were drawn up on a piece of ground called Fair-Lawn, nearly as ≈øome gentlemen have repre≈øented who were examined before me, and ≈øome guards po≈øted between Fair-Lawn and Girardeau's landing, and I believe one at the landing, as I heard a firing which appeared to be at that place.
Q. Where did the enemy land?
A. At Girardeau's landing.
Q. Do you know what force the enemy landed?

Q. What was the compo≈øition and number of the army under General Howe?
A. The number I do not certainly know, but I believe they were about 600, exclu≈øive of the militia; they con≈øi≈øted of the Georgia and South-Carolina troops.
Q. In what manner did the main body of the enemy approach, and what re≈øi≈øtance was made?
A. The enemy fir≈øt approached in front of our troops, but very little re≈øi≈øtance was made, as the troops retreated immediately after it was known the enemy were gaining our right.
Q. When, and in what manner did the army retreat?

A. The army retreated immediately after I reported to General Howe that the enemy were gaining our right, and in column, the South-Carolina in front, the artillery in the centre, and the Georgia in the rear.
Q. What was the lo≈øs in men, cannon and ≈øtores, and by what means were they lo≈øt?

Q. When, where and in what manner did the army cro≈øs Savanna river?
A. The army cro≈ø≈øed Savanna river at the Si≈øters a few days after the 29th in boats.
Q. Do you know of any orders given to the troops at Augu≈øta and Sunbury to leave the State?
A. I do not.
Q. Was there any confu≈øion in the retreat?

A. Not the lea≈øt confu≈øion among the continental troops as long as I ≈øtaid with them, having left them near the burying-ground, at 3 or 400 yards from where the retreat commenced, and went into Savanna to di≈øpatch my ≈øervant with my baggage, whom I ordered to hold him≈øelf in readine≈øs.
Q. by General Howe. What was the fir≈øt duty you were ≈øent upon, after being an extra Aid to me?
A. To reconnoitre the enemy and the ground between Fair-Lawn and Girardeau's landing.
Q. What guards were between the troops at Fair-Lawn and the enemy?

A. There was one on the road leading to Girardeau's hou≈øe, another in a wood ≈øtill nearer to it, and I heard of and believe there was another at the landing before mentioned, as I heard a firing which appeared to be at that place.
Q. What was the di≈øtance from the po≈øition at Fair-Lawn to the place where the enemy landed?
A. About a mile and a half.
Q. What is the di≈øtance between Girardeau's hou≈øe and the landing place, and what is the nature of the ground?

A. I ≈øuppo≈øe it may be about 500 yards from the landing place to Girardeau's hou≈øe; there was a cau≈øeway leading directly from the landing to the hou≈øe; there were ≈øeveral ditches al≈øo leading thro' a rice-field different ways; the dirt thrown out of them made banks which appeared dry enough to walk on; ≈øo appeared the field to be generally, tho' I was not on the field.
Q. Did the enemy's ≈øhipping command the landing-place?
A. Yes; I think effectually.
Q. Are you acquainted with the mora≈øs in front of our po≈øition at Fair-Lawn, what is the nature of it, and of the ground on each ≈øide of it?

A. I think I am acquainted with the nature of the ground, as I cro≈ø≈øed the creek in front of our troops that were drawn up near the mora≈øs, which appeared to me deep, and impracticable for troops to cro≈øs in order. After the bridge was taken up, I found difficulty in getting my hor≈øe over, tho' planks were laid down for that purpo≈øe. The mora≈øs on each ≈øide of the creek, e≈øpecially on the ≈øide of Fair-Lawn, appeared very boggy, and I think impa≈ø≈øable for troops.
Q. Could the mora≈øs directly in our front be ≈øeen by per≈øons approaching it until they came near it?
A. I think not, as the mora≈øs was wide, the de≈øcent ≈øudden, and at a di≈øtance appeared like a plain.
Q. Did you, from any conver≈øation that pa≈ø≈øed between us, or from any other circum≈øtance, under≈øtand whether or not I was acquainted with the pa≈øs of which the enemy availed them≈øelves?

A. I thought you were acquainted with the ground from your ≈øending me ≈øeveral times to vi≈øit it, and from your ≈øeeming apprehen≈øive of danger, ≈øhould the enemy pa≈øs that way. I don't know certainly to this minute where the enemy did pa≈øs.
Q. Did I or did I not expre≈øs to you my apprehen≈øion of the enemy pa≈ø≈øing on my right, and de≈øired you and Major Dehey≈øer alternately to watch them clo≈øely?
A. I don't recollect any particular conver≈øation on that ≈øubject, but well remember you ≈øent Major Dehey≈øer and my≈øelf to examine the ground, which we did, and reported to you.
Q. Was there any hor≈øe po≈øted that way?
A. Yes; there was a party of volunteer hor≈øe po≈øted in a wood, near the ≈øwamp on our right.
Q. Did any parties patrole on our right?

Q. When I was informed that the enemy was gaining my right, what ≈øteps were taken?

A. I remember to have informed General Howe the enemy had pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øwamp on our right, when he ordered a retreat, and ≈øent me to take off a picquet which was po≈øted on our right, and direct the officer to take the neare≈øt route on the flanks of our army to Spring-hill defile.

Q. Did you ≈øee me in the retreat, and what were your ob≈øervations?
A. I ≈øaw you on the flanks of the army, and you appeared to be attentive to the troops.
Q. Where did you join me after you had been ≈øent with orders to the picquet on the right?
A. I joined you on the plain near the burying-ground, and as well as I recollect there was a road that led into Savanna.

Q. By what way did you make your retreat from the town of Savanna?
A. After being detained ≈øome time enquiring for my ≈øervant, I retreated over M'Gilvray's creek, ≈øome di≈øtance below the Spring-hill defile.
Q. Was it pa≈ø≈øable for troops, or otherwi≈øe?
A. It was by no means pa≈ø≈øable for troops in order, though they might have e≈øcaped that way, as I got over with ≈øome difficulty.

A. Not that I recollect.

A. I made an attempt to go that way, but hearing a ≈ømart fire, which appeared to be at that place, I was induced to belive the enemy had taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and that I was too late.
Q. Did the country in the vicinity of Savanna abound with waggons and teams?
A. I believe not.
Q. Do you know of any militia arriving at Savanna from South-Carolina?
A. Yes; a party commanded by Colonel Bull.
Q by General Howe. Did you ≈øee me riding to the right of the army, previous to the action of 29th December?
A. Yes; I ≈øaw you once or twice in the cour≈øe of the day through a wood on the right of the army, and on the ≈øame ≈øide of the ≈øwamp with it.
Lieutenant Gla≈øcock ≈øworn.
Q. Were you in the army in Georgia, at the time the Briti≈øh troops under the command of Colonel Campbell invaded that State?
A. I was.

A. As Lieutenant in the fir≈øt regiment in the Georgia brigade.

A. I only know of one detachment ≈øent to oppo≈øe the landing of the enemy, which was from the Georgia brigade, commanded by Lieutenant Mo≈øeby.

Q. Were the di≈øpo≈øitions, in ca≈øe of a retreat, mentioned in general orders previous to the action?
A. Yes they were, and we were to retreat, if di≈øper≈øed, to the road where the fork leads to M'Gilvray's hou≈øe, as well as I recollect.

Q. Did they continue in good order while the column was pre≈øerved?

A. The rear platoons, of cour≈øe, were obliged to wait for tho≈øe advanced in front.

A. None.

A. They did.
Q. At what place did they go into town?
A. Near the centre.
Q. Did they receive any orders to that purpo≈øe that you know of?
A. None.
Q. Was any detachment made from your brigade to reinforce the guard at Girardeau's landing on the 28th December?
A. Only Lieutenant Mo≈øeby's detachment, which I have already mentioned.
Q. by the Court. Do you know the rea≈øon of the column's being changed from platoons to files, or did you hear General Elbert give any rea≈øon for that manoeuvre?

A. It appeared to me that the arrangement of the Georgia brigade was changed from the enemy's cannon being directed at the column, and a ≈øhot ≈øtriking near the centre, and immediately an alteration took place, but I do not recollect of ever hearing General Elbert give it as a rea≈øon.

A. Four or five.
Q. by the Court. Did you ≈øee General Howe with the Georgia brigade, after that change of di≈øpo≈øition was made?
A. Not that I recollect.

Q. Were you in the army in Georgia, at the time that the Briti≈øh troops under the command of Colonel Campbell invaded that State?
A. I was, and acted as Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary General of I≈ø≈øues to the continental troops that were there, and Commi≈ø≈øary General of Purcha≈øes and I≈ø≈øues to the militia.

Q. When you applied to General Howe on the 25th of December, did you inform him that there was a ≈øufficient quantity of ve≈ø≈øels for the removal of provi≈øions?
A. I told General Howe that there was a number of ve≈ø≈øels at the wharff, if I had authority to impre≈øs them.
Q. by General Howe. Was the flour and beef, ≈øet forth in your te≈øtimony, all continental property?

A. No; becau≈øe ≈øhe could not have gone up the river if ≈øhe was loaded.
Q. by the Court. By who≈øe orders were the 240 barrels of flour (mentioned in your an≈øwer to General Howe's que≈øtion) removed?

A. They were not; they were left on the wharff, as the Spaniard who was to have taken them on board ≈øhipped his fa≈øt and ran up the river on the appearance of the ve≈ø≈øels of the enemy.
The Court adjourned till to-morrow morning, ten o'clock.

Captain John Budd ≈øworn.
Q. Were you in the army when Colonel Campbell invaded Georgia?
A. Yes.
Q. In what capacity did you act?
A. As a Lieutenant in Colonel Roberts's regiment of artillery.
Q. Do you know what ≈øteps were taken by General Howe to prevent the enemy landing?
A. As there is ≈øuch a length of time elap≈øed, I do not recollect any particular circum≈øtance relative to the di≈øpo≈øitions of the army.
Q. What was your po≈øt in the column in the retreat?
A. Immediately in front of the Georgia brigade.
Q. What was your po≈øt in the line in the time of action?
A. On the right of the continentals.
Q. Do you recollect at what period of the retreat the Georgia brigade quitted the line of march?

A. I do not recollect at what particular period, but the fir≈øt I ob≈øerved of their being gone was when we wanted them to ≈øupport the field-piece when we arrived on the hill, where one of our hor≈øes and driver were ≈øhot, which was the means of our lo≈øing the piece.
Q. How far were you advanced in front of the Georgia brigade when the army took up their line of march on the retreat?
A. About twenty or thirty paces.
Q. How far di≈øtant from the town was the hill you ≈øpeak of?

Q. How far was the rear of the South-Carolina brigade advanced in your front at the time you halted?

A. There were three field-pieces and two ammunition-waggons between the infantry and the field-piece with which I was, and we were as clo≈øe as we could be to the ammunition-waggon when we halted, and the front of the artillery clo≈øe to the rear of the South-Carolina brigade.

A. Not belonging to the continental troops.
Q. Did you fire your field-piece in the line, before the retreat commenced?
A. Yes; we did fire four or five times with round ≈øhot, at the di≈øtance of 150 paces.

A. We had a great quantity of grape, but no ca≈øe.
Q. by General Howe. Did you ≈øee me in the cour≈øe of the retreat, and where?

A. Yes; I ≈øaw you ≈øpeaking to Colonel Roberts immediately on the right of the field-piece with which I was, about mid-way between Spring-hill defile and Fair-Lawn, when Colonel Roberts told us that it was the orders for us to go on as quick as po≈ø≈øibly we could.

Q. Were you in the American army when Colonel Campbell invaded Georgia, and in what capacity?
A. I was, and in the capacity of Colonel Commandant of the Georgia brigade.
Q. Do you know how long previous to the inva≈øion of Georgia General Howe received intelligence of the de≈øigns of the enemy, and what ≈øteps were taken by him in con≈øequence?

A. I don't know that General Howe had any previous information of the de≈øigns of the enemy to invade the State of Georgia. Some time about the beginning of November 1778, being in Charles-Town on bu≈øine≈øs of the public, where General Howe then was, accounts were received that Colonel Provo≈øt, with a con≈øiderable force from Ea≈øt-Florida, had invaded that State. I immediately received the General's orders to return to Georgia, where, I think the ≈øecond day after my arrival, I was joined by him, who informed me that he had ordered ≈øome continental troops from the State of South-Carolina to our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and that ≈øome militia of that State were a≈ø≈øembling for the like purpo≈øe; the latter, after being ≈øome days in Georgia, returned. Colonel Provo≈øt having retreated before their arrival, part of the continentals ordered from South-Carolina were brought into Georgia, and the remainder po≈øted at Pury≈øburgh. Nearly about the time of Colonel Provo≈øt's inva≈øion, a ve≈ø≈øel arrived at Tybee, and after remaining a day or two ≈øailed again. From this ve≈ø≈øel we had a de≈øerter, who informed that ≈øhe was a tran≈øport with Briti≈øh troops on board, and one of a con≈øiderable fleet that had ≈øailed from New-York to invade the State. Some time the latter end of December, a fleet appeared upon the coa≈øt, and a few days after arrived at Tybee; upon which General Howe drew all the troops of the State and tho≈øe of South-Carolina before-mentioned to Savanna, except a garri≈øon left in the ≈øort at Sunbury, and Colonel Marbury's regiment po≈øted at Augu≈øta. On the 28th December, the enemy's fleet proceeded up the river Savanna, the van of which anchored nearly oppo≈øite Girardeau's, where, from ≈øome of their movements, it was judged they would attempt to land their troops. In the evening of that day I was at the above place with General Howe and ≈øeveral other officers, reconnoitering the enemy. The General, on leaving the place, reque≈øted that I would remain and po≈øt a picquet he had ordered there, and de≈øired that I would order the officer commanding the picquet to cau≈øe the dam leading from the river to the hill to be cut acro≈øs. When the picquet arrived, I po≈øted them in the manner that I thought would be≈øt an≈øwer the purpo≈øe for which they were ≈øent, and gave the officer the orders I had in charge from the General. I then marked out the ground where I judged it nece≈ø≈øary to throw up ≈øome works, and told the officer I would go to the General and try to have his party, which con≈øi≈øted of only thirty men, con≈øiderably reinforced, and at the ≈øame time obtain an order to have ≈øome entrenching tools ≈øent down. I waited upon the General, and informed him that I had every rea≈øon to believe that the enemy intended to land at Girardeau's, and recommended to him to have the picquet there con≈øiderably reinforced, and reque≈øted that he would immediately order ≈øome entrenching tools to the place, as the party was entirely without. I am not certain, but I believe I recommended at the ≈øame time to the General to ≈øend a field-piece or two to the ≈øame place. His reply was, that he would con≈øider of it, and reque≈øted that I would call on him in an hour or two. On my return to the General, at about ten or eleven o'clock at night, I under≈øtood him that the entrenching tools were ≈øent. With re≈øpect to the reinforcement, he told me that he could not ≈øpare more than 20 men, which he reque≈øted that I would go down with. I did ≈øo, and on my arrival was ≈øurprized to find that no tools were at the place. It being then too late to obtain them, ≈øo as to be of any ≈øervice, I told Captain Smith, who commanded the picquet, that at day-light I did not doubt but he would ≈øee the enemy landed, and recommended that he would re≈øerve his fire until they got within 50 or 60 yards, then to commence a cool, deliberate fire, and retreat up until he was either ≈øupported or forced from his ground. As I judged it happened, but the party were ≈øoon forced from the hill, when the enemy gained footing a little after day-light, and were the mo≈øt of that day, the 29th, in full view, landing their troops and artillery, without the lea≈øt interruption from us.
Q. Do you know what force the enemy landed?
A. The force with which the enemy invaded the State amounted to full 3000 men. I believe they had about 2000 landed when they advanced towards us.
Q. What was the compo≈øition and number of the army under General Howe?
A. Between 5 and 600 continental troops, and a detachment of artillery with four or five field-pieces, and about 100 militia.
Q. In what manner did the main body of the enemy approach, and what re≈øi≈øtance was made?

A. The enemy advanced in two columns, their right along a path leading through Sir James Wright's plantation, halting in full view of us at a place called Gay's, their left down the main road leading from Girardeau's to Savanna; while we were amu≈øed by the fir≈øt column in front, the latter filed by their left, along a bye-path leading through the back of Milledge's old field, and acro≈øs a ≈øwamp upon our right to an open pine barren at the back of the new barracks, where they were met by the militia under Colonel Walton, who, after a ≈ømart ≈økirmi≈øh, were forced from their ground. I know of no other re≈øi≈øtance, except by the picquet at Girardeau's, and the firing of a few field-pieces in the front of our line that was made to the enemy.
Q. When, and in what manner did the army retreat?

A. Between three and four o'clock in the afternoon of the 29th, the army was ordered to retire in the following order; the South-Carolina troops to retreat fir≈øt to the Spring-hill, and there form and cover the retreat of the artilletry and Georgia troops, the latter to form ≈øomewhere about M'Gilvray's path, and there remain, until joined by the former. Our army was formed acro≈øs the road leading from Savanna to Girardeau's, near half a mile below the town, under a hill of ea≈øy a≈øcent in an open field, with a ravine in front, Tatnall's buildings better than 100 yards on our right, and Governor Wright's barn about the ≈øame di≈øtance on our left, with a traver≈øe acro≈øs the road in our centre with two field-pieces, and a field-piece advanced in front of each wing; on our right was a ≈øwamp, ≈øome di≈øtance up which, at the back of Tatnall's buildings, a path led from Milledge's to town; on this path a work was thrown up, in which was po≈øted a detachment of continental ≈øoldiers, and to the right of this, up the ≈øame ≈øwamp, I under≈øtood the militia were to have been po≈øted. Our left was in ≈øome degree covered by a battery at ≈øome di≈øtance wide of its rear, which commanded part of a low rice-field not very acce≈ø≈øible. As ≈øoon as the enemy, who were in our front, ob≈øerved the Carolina troops go off the field and our artillery limbered, they moved bri≈økly forward, and commenced a ≈øharp cannonade on the Georgia brigade, which was formed in a clo≈øe column by ≈øections by the left, with the left in front. As ≈øoon as the artillery moved off the field, I faced the column to the right about, and retired in that order. As we cro≈ø≈øed the road, the enemy's artillery made ≈øome impre≈ø≈øion on the column, notwith≈øtanding which it pre≈øerved perfect good order. Ju≈øt as we gained the ≈øummit of the hill, a heavy fire of mu≈øquetry commenced towards our left, when I perceived our artillery go off on a full gallop. I moved as quick as I po≈ø≈øibly could without getting into di≈øorder. About 100 yards before I got to the ≈øouthea≈øt extremity of the town, a body of the enemy, advanced to the ea≈øt of the new barracks, commenced a heavy fire of mu≈øquetry on our left flank; at the ≈øame time ob≈øerving the Carolina brigade beyond the ≈øouthwe≈øt extremity of the town, in ≈øome di≈øorder, pu≈øhing for the Spring-hill, and a body of the enemy near that place keeping up a ≈ømart fire on them, I judged it too late for me to attempt that defile, as the enemy mu≈øt be in full po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it before I could po≈ø≈øibly reach it. In this ≈øituation, with the enemy in front, flank and rear, I formed the de≈øign of attempting to force my way up the Ogechee road, where I ob≈øerved the enemy's line to be the weake≈øt, and with this view ordered my light infantry to advance and attack the enemy on my flanks, to draw their fire while I reduced the column, and to divert their attention from my main de≈øign. Immediately after the order to the light infantry, as we advanced, I ordered an open column, as ≈øoon as I ≈øaw that there was a proper di≈øtance between the ≈øections, which happened ju≈øt as we were behind the burying-ground. I lo≈øt no more time than was nece≈ø≈øary for the following words of command: Halt: Sections, to the left face: By files to the right wheel: March. Before I got the rear well clear of the burying-ground, the line broke about the centre, and the whole, except three or four ≈øections, fell up one of the ≈øtreets. Ob≈øerving the few that followed me, I led them through where a ≈øquare of buildings had but late been burnt down, and halted before the Court-hou≈øe door, which being a brick building, I had thought of throwing my≈øelf into it, but previous to taking this ≈øtep, I determined to con≈øult Colonel Harris, the next officer in command to my≈øelf. I called him to me, and a≈øked if he could recommend any place through which I could effect a retreat? he an≈øwered that we might get over Mu≈øgrove's creek. I ob≈øerved to him that it was a full tide, and that the creek could not be pa≈ø≈øable. He replied that there was a log, which he had been fifty times over. I replied, lead me to it, it is a happy circum≈øtance, we will ≈øave our men; and called out, Follow me, ≈øoldiers, and I will conduct you to a ≈øafe retreat. I heard the words, Follow the commandant, frequently repeated; and le≈øt they might not know what I intended, I kept waving my ≈øword over my head, and moved ≈ølowly on at the head of the few that yet pre≈øerved their order, and ≈øent Colonel Harris back to the rear with orders to pu≈øh them on, and de≈øired that he would join me in time before I got to the creek. This he did, but when we got there he could not find the log, owing I ≈øuppo≈øe to the high tide. As the only alternative, I then ordered the ≈øoldiers to ≈øwim the creek; a few obeyed my command, others alledged that they could not ≈øwim. The enemy, who had got po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Spring-hill defile, moved down and kept a ≈ømart fire on us, and, rather than be taken pri≈øoner, I ≈øaved my≈øelf by ≈øwimming, as did Colonel Harris. Major Grimkie, one of the General's Aids, ≈øwam a little above where I did.
Q. What was the lo≈øs in men, cannon and ≈øtores, and by what means were they lo≈øt?

A. The manner in which the Georgia troops were lo≈øt I have already an≈øwered; re≈øpecting tho≈øe of South-Carolina I can't ≈øay. I believe the number of continental troops lo≈øt that day exceeded 200. One field-piece was taken from the militia, another from the continental artillery, owing, as I was informed, to the driver being killed. Five other long bra≈øs field-pieces not properly mounted, that were removed out of town, with a quantity of ammunition, in con≈øequence of our misfortune fell into the enemy's hands. Several iron pieces, with a quantity of ≈øtores that it was impo≈ø≈øible to move after the enemy made their appearance, were likewi≈øe lo≈øt.
Q. When did the army cro≈øs Savanna river, and in what manner?
A. I don't know.
Q. Do you know of any orders given to the troops at Augu≈øta and Sunbury to leave the State?

A. The General informed me of the orders he had ≈øent to the garri≈øon of Sunbury. I don't recollect what they exactly were, but they were ≈øuch as I approved of at the time, and only lament they were not obeyed. With re≈øpect to the orders given to the troops at Augu≈øta I can't ≈øay.
Q. What was the number of militia belonging to the State of Georgia?
A. I believe the whole militia of the State of Georgia amounted to about 3000 men.
Q. When the inva≈øion of Georgia took place, what proportion of militia was reque≈øted by General Howe of the executive authority?

A. About the time of the inva≈øion General Howe was frequently with the Governor, and at that time I am certain the General informed me of every material matter that pa≈ø≈øed between them; but at this time I don't recollect any particulars of con≈øequence, tho' to the be≈øt of my belief he repre≈øented to the Governor, that as many militia as could be collected would be nece≈ø≈øary.
Q. Do you know the numbers actually in the field at that time?
A. No.
Q. Do you know of any previous di≈øpo≈øitions made by General Howe, in ca≈øe of a retreat?
A. The general orders before-mentioned, that were i≈ø≈øued re≈øpecting the mode of retreating, if nece≈ø≈øary, may be deemed a previous di≈øpo≈øition. I know of no other.
Q. Were the militia of the State of Georgia in general armed, and in what manner?
A. The militia of the State of Georgia were in general but indifferently armed. Tho≈øe belonging to the town of Savanna I judged to be very well armed.
Q. What is the general face of the country in the vicinity of Savanna?

A. The town of Savanna ≈øtands on a high ≈øandy ridge, which terminates in a bluff near a mile in extent on the river. This ridge runs backward, upwards of two miles, nearly the ≈øame width, and is a remarkable level open pine-barren. On each ≈øide of the ridge a creek empties into the river, which occa≈øions two ≈øwamps, both of which, rather farther back than the tows, are cultivated, the uncultivated parts are very thickly wooded; that to the ≈øouth-ea≈øt of the town is pa≈ø≈øable in many places; the other, to the ≈øouth-we≈øt of the town, is ≈øcarcely pa≈ø≈øable but where the road runs through it. On the oppo≈øite ≈øide of the ≈øwamp, below the town, is Girardeau's place, a bluff 40 or 50 feet high, and ridge nearly ≈øimilar to that on which the town ≈øtands, with this difference, that the ridge terminates nearly three quarters of a mile from the river, and leaves a remarkably level ≈øwamp, overflowed by every ≈øpring-tide.
Q. Were the army in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a proportion of entrenching tools to erect works?
A. I don't believe that the army had a proper ≈øupply of entrenching tools, but I am certain that a ≈øufficient quantity could have been obtained to throw up works that would have been of ≈øervice.
Q. What were the applications made at different times by General Howe to the legi≈ølative and executive authority of the State for means of defending it?
A. With re≈øpect to any further applications I don't recollect.
Q. by the Court. Do you know what rea≈øons operated to prevent the enemy's being oppo≈øed in landing their troops?
A. No.
Q. Had the enemy any ve≈ø≈øels of force to cover the landing of their troops?
A. Yes, and from the di≈øpo≈øitions of tho≈øe ve≈ø≈øels, I judged they intended landing at that place.

Q. by General Howe. Were or were not the legi≈ølative and executive bodies of the State of Georgia, at different times, frequently applied to by me, both per≈øonally and by letter, to fortify the country at particular places, be≈øide other mea≈øures ≈øtrongly recommended by me for the general defence of the State?
A. Yes, I believe they were.
Q. Did you ever ≈øee any letters of mine to that State for that purpo≈øe?

A. Some con≈øiderable time before the inva≈øion, I recollect ≈øeeing a letter from you, very fully on that ≈øubject, laid before the A≈ø≈øembly, which gave offence; in con≈øequence, as I apprehended, of your attempting to dictate to them.
Colonel Marbury ≈øworn.
Q. Were you in the army in Georgia, when the enemy under Colonel Campbell invaded that State?
A. I was.
Q. In what capacity did you act?

A. I had the command of a regiment, but it was not pre≈øent. The day previous to the 29th of December I arrived at Savanna, and acted as Aid to General Howe on the latter part of the day the enemy landed.
Q. Do you know how long previous to the inva≈øion of Georgia General Howe received intelligence of the de≈øigns of the enemy, and what ≈øteps were taken by him in con≈øequence?

A. I do not know when General Howe received the intelligence, and as I was out of town, do not know what ≈øteps were taken previous to the evening of the 28th December, 1778, when I joined the General about ≈øun-≈øet at Girardeau's. He was then, in company with ≈øeveral gentlemen of the army, reconnoitering the ground, and ≈øpoke of it's being very defen≈øible.
Q. Do you know what force the enemy landed?
A. It was generally ≈øaid, and I believe they landed at lea≈øt 2000 men.
Q. What was the compo≈øition and number of the army under General Howe?
A. About 500 continentals, with a detachment of Colonel Roberts's artillery, four or five field pieces, and about 100 militia.
Q. In what manner did the main body of the enemy approach, and what re≈øi≈øtance was made?

A. They advanced in two columns, one by the path leading thro' Sir James Wright's plantations, the other on the main road leading to Savanna. They appeared in full view at Gay's gate, from a little below which place a detachment filed off, and thro' a thick ≈øwamp gained our right and charged Colonel Walton, who, with about 80 militia and a field-piece, was po≈øted back of the new barracks, and from the enemy's great ≈øuperiority of numbers was obliged to leave the ground, and retreat precipitately after a ≈øhort engagement. I don't know of any other re≈øi≈øtance made, except a few ≈øhot from the artillery in front of our army, before a retreat was made, and a fire from Captain Smith, who commanded the party at Girardeau's, on the enemy, as they advanced to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Girardeau's hill.
Q. When, and in what manner did the army retreat?

A. I was not on the ground when the retreat was ordered; but I think about or a little after three o'clock, as I was going with a requi≈øition from Colonel Walton to the General for troops to ≈øupport him, I met General Howe, at the head of the Carolineans, retreating, about half way between Tatnall's and the town. They were then in good order.
Q. What was the lo≈øs in men, cannon and ≈øtores, and by what means were they lo≈øt?
A. I do not know the lo≈øs of either, nor can I account by what means.
Q. When did the army cro≈øs Savanna river, and in what manner?

A. On the night of the 30th General Howe reached Treutlan's, which is about 45 miles above Savanna, and ≈øent out to ≈øecure the boats, and began to cro≈øs the baggage on the morning following at the Two Si≈øters.
Q. Do you know of any orders given to the troops at Augu≈øta and Sunbury to leave the State?

A. After we had retreated to Cherokee hill, about eight miles from Savanna, the General ≈øent Captain Wood with orders to the officer commanding the troops at Sunbury to evacuate the fort, to retreat and join the General. On the next day, or day after, Major Dehey≈øer was ≈øent to Augu≈øta, with orders for the troops ≈øtationed there to cro≈øs the river, and join the continental army wherever they might be.
Q. What were the number of militia belonging to the State of Georgia?
A. I think there was about two thou≈øand five hundred men.

A. I do not know.

A. I don't know.

A. I do not.

A. I think it is about half a mile.

A. They were badly armed.

A. I am not well enough acquainted with the place to de≈øcribe it.

A. I do not know.

A. I have heard mention made of frequent applications, but cannot attempt to ≈øay what they were.
Q. by General Howe. What were the orders given you by me on that day, and other circum≈øtances that pa≈ø≈øed between us?

A. On the evening of the 28th December 1778, after returning from Girardeau's with General Howe, he reque≈øted that I would collect three or four gentlemen, and patrole the country that night between the ≈øea and Savanna, to ob≈øerve if any of the enemy had landed below, or if any of the country people appeared to be going to the Briti≈øh ve≈ø≈øels. I did ≈øo, and returned ju≈øt about day-break, and ≈øoon after a firing commenced by Captain Smith at Girardeau's, who was ≈øoon forced from his po≈øt, and it occupied by the Briti≈øh. A little after I returned to town, and about twelve o'clock rode to head-quarters at Tatnall's hou≈øe, in company with Colonel Huger and General Elbert. They informed me that the General had called a council, wherein it was determined to remain on the ground where they were and receive the enemy. Tho≈øe gentlemen informed General Howe that they had ju≈øt returned from reconnoitering the ground on our right, that the ≈øwamp was pa≈ø≈øable, and they did not like their ≈øituation. The General ≈øaid he was not well plea≈øed with it, or words to that purpo≈øe, and reque≈øted tho≈øe gentlemen to take the opinions of the officers who had compo≈øed the council. Some little time after this, the General reque≈øted me to take a view of the ground, and immediately return to him; I did ≈øo, and gave information ≈øimilar to what he had before received. I a≈øked the General if he thought it would be ami≈øs to ≈øend a company to the place where it was thought the enemy would cro≈øs the ≈øwamp, about a quarter of a mile higher up, where there was a ≈ømall brea≈øt-work, occupied by Captain Keith of South-Carolina, with a company of regular troops, I think about 30 or 40. He ≈øaid it was a lucky thought, and reque≈øted me to take the command. Having no other at that time, my regiment being in Augu≈øta, I accepted it chearfully. The General de≈øired me to ride up and look out a convenient place, and he would order up the men. He ≈øent Major Grimkie, his Aid, directly after me, who informed me that the militia under Colonel Walton were to occupy the ground I ≈øpoke of, and that he ≈øhould not ≈øend up any regulars. I then returned to the General, told him that I did not wi≈øh to remain as an idle ≈øpectator, and would be glad he would employ me. He told me to remain with him, and if the enemy advanced I might be of ≈øervice. A little after the enemy appeared in view, and the General reque≈øted me to go up and remain on the right between, and have an eye on the brea≈øt-work and the militia. I went up, and about three o'clock (I think) the enemy appeared, and ≈øhortly after formed on an eminence that the militia had left a little before, and which Colonel Walton attempted to regain, but was too late. The militia appeared in confu≈øion, and could not be reduced to order. A field-piece was fired once or twice in front of the militia, and though the Colonel prevailed on them to advance and gave them three cheers, they were ≈øtill in confu≈øion. I a≈øked him if it would not be nece≈ø≈øary to get a ≈øupport of regulars. He reque≈øted me to ride to General Howe, to inform him of his ≈øituation, that he would maintain the ground as long as po≈ø≈øible, but was afraid he could not do it long without ≈øupport, and reque≈øted the General to ≈øend a detachment to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. On my way to head-quarters I pa≈ø≈øed near to the ≈ømall work occupied by Captain Keith, who called and informed me that General Howe had retreated, and a≈øked what he had be≈øt do. I pointed out his route, and advi≈øed him to make the be≈øt of his way, and then came up to General Howe, about half way between Tatnall's and town, at the head of the Carolina troops, who were in good order. I let him know Colonel Walton's reque≈øt. He ordered me back to him immediately with orders to retreat; but when I returned behind the barracks, I found the Briti≈øh on the ground, and the militia flying towards the Spring-hill, about 200 yards before me. I did not ≈øee Colonel Walton again, and never got up with the whole of the militia till they had got over the defile that we had to pa≈øs. There in vain I endeavoured to rally them, and on my return met General Howe about the Spring-hill (the troops were then in great confu≈øion) who immediately reque≈øted me to try again to rally the militia, and was the ≈øecond time as un≈øucce≈øsful as the fir≈øt. By the time I returned, the artillery and troops had reached the Red-Hou≈øe, called M'Gilvray's, near the upper end of the defile, where they halted; and after a ≈øhort time the General ≈øent me to Colonel White, who had command of the galleys and other ve≈ø≈øels laying above Race-Hall, to inform him of our retreat and to order him to move up the river with the ve≈ø≈øels, and when at any advantageous
place to come to, in order to prevent any ve≈ø≈øels running up the river and landing men to cut off our retreat; but at the ≈øame time not to remain in any place ≈øo long, as to endanger the ve≈ø≈øels under his command.
Q. Where was the militia po≈øted when you fir≈øt ≈øaw them after you were ≈øent to the right?
A. On a ≈ømall eminence near a branch, at ≈øome di≈øtance from the barracks.

Lieutenant Colonel Ternant was ≈øworn.

Q. At the commencement of the inva≈øion, what ≈øteps were taken by Major General Howe to prevent the enemy landing?

A. From the 24th of December, when the Briti≈øh fleet fir≈øt entered the Savanna river, to the 29th, when the action took place, the General, with Governor Hou≈øton and ≈øeveral officers of the army, vi≈øited the ≈øeveral places where it was mo≈øt probable the enemy would land. I was pre≈øent at tho≈øe reconnoitering excur≈øions. The landing at Girardeau's was generally looked upon as the mo≈øt likely to be cho≈øen by the enemy, which occa≈øioned di≈øcu≈ø≈øion about the means mo≈øt effectual to prevent them, and in general to counteract their operations. It was generally thought nece≈ø≈øary, and as I under≈øtood agreed on between the Governor and General, to erect a battery on the banks of the river, ≈øo as to prevent the approach of the ≈øhipping to the cau≈øeway, and con≈øequently the enemy's landing and taking po≈øt on the bluff. The fort on Savanna was al≈øo to be repaired and enclo≈øed. The high banks rai≈øed along the river, from Savanna-bluff to Girardeau's cau≈øeway, for the purpo≈øe of watering and draining the rice-fields, were to be broken ≈øo as to overflow tho≈øe fields at high water, and render the whole extent of them, from Girardeau's cau≈øeway to the cau≈øeway in front of the troops on Fair-Lawn, as impa≈ø≈øable as po≈ø≈øible, and the≈øe fields without that prevention were then thought pa≈ø≈øable for infantry by files, tho' not without difficulty. Some other field works were likewi≈øe to be made in the vicinity of the place, extended as a po≈øition for the troops, which then might amount to about 650 regulars and about 100 militia. The means nece≈ø≈øary to make the≈øe field preparations being entirely in the hands of the executive of Georgia, ≈øuch as Negroes, tools of all kinds, hor≈øes and gears for the tran≈øportation of artillery, applications were made by the General to procure them. They were promi≈øed ≈øeveral times in my pre≈øence by Governor Hou≈øton, but never furni≈øhed, any further than by ≈øending three Negroes the 26th in the morning with two tools, and the≈øe went away in the evening of the ≈øame day and never appeared again. I heard the General many times expre≈øs his complaints about it, and repeatedly ≈øent his Aids, but to no purpo≈øe. The chief command was even di≈øputed him, which occa≈øioned confu≈øion and delay in every mea≈øure; and how ≈øoon the di≈øpute ended by the Governor giving up the command to the General I can't tell. On the 28th, fix of the enemy's ve≈ø≈øels having come up and anchored oppo≈øite to Girardeau's bluff, the erecting of any battery on the banks of the river became impracticable; upon which a picquet of 50 men was po≈øted at the hou≈øe on the bluff, with an intention, as I heard the General expre≈øs, to watch the motions of the enemy at that place, and oppo≈øe them ≈øo far as to be reinforced in time, whenever it ≈øhould be a≈øcertained that they really intended to land there. On the 29th, early in the morning, a firing was heard at that place, in con≈øequence of the enemy's landing; upon which the General ordered me there, but before I reached half way, I found that and another picquet retreating. I had collected the whole together, when the General joined us, and ordered me to take command of them, and remain on the ≈øpot where we were till further orders. I omitted to ob≈øerve that a mounted militia man was left with the commanding officer of the picquet, to give the earlie≈øt intelligence of the enemy's apparent movements, but who never to my knowledge reported to the General, tho' he was ≈øent in time for that purpo≈øe, as I heard the commanding officer of the picquet ≈øay.
Q. At what di≈øtance from the main body of the army was the place the enemy landed?
A. Between a mile and a mile and an half.

A. I under≈øtood, after the action, they landed upwards of 2000 men at that place.

A. There were ≈øeveral places above and below the town, who≈øe names have partly e≈øcaped my memory, but which rendered every po≈øition that could be taken with an inferior force in the vicinity of the town, for the purpo≈øe of defending it, exceedingly precarious.

A. Parties of militia were po≈øted at each of tho≈øe places below the town, and a picquet of 50 continental troops at Girardeau's, as the mo≈øt probable place of landing. A. Not that I know of.
Q. After it was known that the enemy landed, what mea≈øures were taken to a≈øcertain their numbers and to oppo≈øe them?

A. I cannot ≈øpeak to the fir≈øt part of that que≈øtion, further than that I heard the General ≈øeveral times complain he could get no information to be depended on, either about their force or de≈øigns. About three hours after the enemy had landed, I received orders to return to the army with the advanced picquets, who
immediately joined their re≈øpective corps. Two hours before the action a council of war was called of the field officers of the army, and from the uncertainty of the information procured by the General of the number and de≈øign of the enemy, and to gain as much time as po≈ø≈øible for the removal of public and private property from the town, it was unanimou≈øly agreed that the army ought to remain on the ≈øpot where they were then po≈øted at Fair-Lawn until the views of the enemy could be known, and their ≈øuperiority ≈øo a≈øcertained as to urge and ju≈øtify a retreat. In con≈øequence of that determination, the following di≈øpo≈øition was made and i≈ø≈øued in general orders:

div.head: GENERAL ORDERS and DISPOSITION of the TROOPS.
div.p: THE Carolina troops are to be told off into 16 platoons of eight files each, with the remaining files formed on their right as light infantry; the whole to be commanded by Colonel Huger. The Georgia troops to be formed into eight platoons of ten files each, with the remaining files on their left as light infantry; the whole to be commanded by General Elbert. The officers to take po≈øt as u≈øual by ≈øeniority in their re≈øpective lines. Tho≈øe who do not command platoons to fall in the rear of them as bringers-up, the better to pre≈øerve order and regularity through the line. Both corps to be formed in columns; tho≈øe of Carolina by platoons on their right, and the others likewi≈øe by platoons on their left, and to remain in that formation, with the light infantry at the head of each column, until further orders. The artillery to remain in its pre≈øent po≈øition, and to be in the utmo≈øt readine≈øs to move or act as occa≈øion may require. The General reque≈øts and expects that both officers and men will di≈øtingui≈øh them≈øelves by their firmne≈øs and per≈øeverance, and by an exact ob≈øervance of orders. Should they be compelled to retreat, it is to be in the following order. The troops will move off in columns in the order ≈øet forth. The light infantry of Carolina to form the advance guard, to march rapidly by the ≈øhorte≈øt route to the Spring-hill defile, which they will po≈ø≈øe≈øs on both ≈øides and endeavour to maintain. The artillery, all but one field-piece, will follow the Carolina brigade, and Colonel Roberts, when he arrives at the defile, will po≈øt his pieces ≈øo as be≈øt to cover the retreat of the Georgia brigade; Colonel Huger, his men ≈øo as mo≈øt effectually to an≈øwer the ≈øame purpo≈øe, and to ≈øecure the artillery. The Georgia troops will follow their light infantry with a field-piece, forming the rear of the line, and as ≈øoon as they reach the defile this colomn, with the whole of the artillery, will pa≈øs and form on the other ≈øide of it, in ≈øuch manner as the commanding officer ≈øhall think be≈øt to prevent in≈øults from the enemy, and to ≈øecure the retreat of the troops from the head of the defile. Should a root take place, the troops are to re-a≈ø≈øemble beyond the defile at M'Gilvray's road. Further orders are to be applied for, or will be given, as circum≈øtances ≈øhall require.

I was then ≈øent again to reconnoitre the pa≈ø≈øes through the ≈øwamp on our right, and was accompanied by two militia-men who≈øe names I do not recollect. The principal gap was defended by a ≈øtrong picquet, who≈øe numbers I have forgot, and a redan which occupied the whole ≈øpace of the pa≈ø≈øage. The other pa≈øs was that mentioned to exi≈øt about a quarter of a mile further; I immediately went to vi≈øit it; we attempted three times to go through the ≈øwamp at that place, and upon my guides pronouncing it impracticable we returned to the troops on Fair-Lawn. The General then ordered me to join a body of militia intended as a further ≈øecurity to his right flank, and to po≈øt them in ≈øuch a manner as be≈øt to an≈øwer that object. I found them drawn up in one rank to the number of ninety-three, with a field-piece, nearly oppo≈øite to the pa≈øs la≈øt mentioned. They being a too great di≈øtance from the ≈øwamp, it was thought be≈øt to advance them clo≈øer to it; but before the nece≈ø≈øary movements could be performed with that irregular body, the enemy's light infantry came out of the ≈øwamp, filing off to the right and left, ≈øo as to come on the flanks of the militia, who from that moment would not be prevailed on to make the ≈ømalle≈øt alteration in their actual po≈øition. As ≈øoon as I ≈øaw the enemy from the ≈øwamp, I ordered a mounted militia-man to go and acquaint the General with it. Mean while the field-piece was directed to fire on the thicke≈øt of the enemy, and the militia encouraged to keep their ground, until the enemy by approaching higher would be fired upon and ≈økirmi≈øhed with, ≈øo as to cover as far as in their power the retreat of the troops on Fair-Lawn. As ≈øoon as the enemy, who had performed this angular evolution out of the reach of mu≈øquetry, had arrived to both wings of the militia, they marched bri≈økly, or rather ru≈øhed with great ≈øhouts. The militia, probably ≈øtruck with the ≈øuperiority of the enemy, who amounted to about 700 men, broke without firing, and fled towards the Spring-hill cau≈øeway; a few only fired their mu≈øquets in retiring. Upon this the enemy poured in a heavy fire, and as ≈øoon as the field-piece was ≈øpiked up I attempted to join the continental troops, whom I met about a hundred yards to the we≈øtward of the barracks, retreating in tolerable good order, except tho≈øe of Georgia under General Elbert, who, contrary to the di≈øpo≈øition, had quitted the line of march and gone into the town. I marched with the troops to the defile. Two hou≈øes that ≈øtood on each ≈øide of it were occupied for a few minutes, and when all hopes of the Georgia troops arriving were over, and the enemy pre≈ø≈øing upon us, the troops with the artillery, except one field-piece, got over the cau≈øeway, and made a halt of a few minutes on the other ≈øide of it.

Q. by General Howe. Were the reports of the inva≈øion given by the de≈øerter, ≈øaid to come from the tran≈øport, previous to the retreat of the troops that invaded Georgia from St. Augu≈øtine, or afterwards?
A. They reached us at Sunbury, after the retreat of tho≈øe troops to Frederica.
