div.head: JANUARY 21≈øt.
div.p: The Court met agreeable to adjournment.
Major General Howe proceeds in his defence as follows:

p.hi: Mr. Pre≈øident, and Gentlemen of the Court,

div.p:
CONSCIOUS as I am that I have to the utmo≈øt of my abilities endeavoured to ≈øerve my country‚Äîthat from principle I entered into the pre≈øent conte≈øt with the earlie≈øt, re≈øolved not to retire but with the late≈øt, or at lea≈øt not until my life or American grievances had a period‚Äîthat my zeal in the common cau≈øe was equal to any, and that my ardor to promote it could be exceeded by none‚ÄîI little dreamed that I ≈øhould at this day, or indeed on any other, have ≈øtood arraigned at a military tribunal for imputed crimes, which malice would ≈øtrive to magnify and fix upon me, and by which my reputation might, for a time at lea≈øt, be held in ≈øu≈øpence, even by the good. How painfully this mu≈øt affect me, let military ≈øen≈øibility determine: For in a profe≈ø≈øion ≈øo cha≈øte as that of arms, where honor is ≈øo feelingly alive that it mu≈øt ≈ømart and agonize at the lea≈øt ≈øhadow of a≈øper≈øion, expre≈ø≈øion can give no proper colourings to my anxieties; indeed it yields me none, but what, compared to my feelings, would be poor and contemptible. Happily for me, however, I am arraigned before a Court where Ju≈øtice, with its delicate auxiliary Honor, ≈øit as Judges; a Court where, of all others, had I been guilty, I ≈øhould be mo≈øt appalled at appearing, but by which, con≈øcious of my innocence, I mo≈øt rejoice to be tried. Tho' it would not perhaps be very difficult to ≈øhew that Georgia, as a State, had very little to do in this pro≈øecution, yet, de≈øirous to be ju≈øtified by facts alone, and fearing no ≈øearch, or re≈øearch, tho' malevolence directs the probe, I ≈øhall admit, for the pre≈øent at lea≈øt, that having been mi≈øunder≈øtood by or mi≈ørepre≈øented to the State of Georgia, they have thought proper to bring me where now you ≈øee me. The charges again≈øt me are heavy‚Äîlet us ≈øee how they have been ≈øupported; and though Colonel Walton is not the fir≈øt, yet, as he is the arch evidence upon this occa≈øion, I ≈øhall begin with him, and the more e≈øpecially, as he ≈øo very comprehen≈øively in his te≈øtimony alludes to every charge brought again≈øt me, that remarking upon his evidence will, in a great mea≈øure, do away the nece≈ø≈øity of de≈øcanting upon the re≈øt. He tells you that the Briti≈øh troops from Ea≈øt Florida penetrated Georgia two ways; that they evidently expected co-operating troops from the northward, which not arriving, they returned. That troops did enter the State in the manner he ≈øays is true; but by what ≈øpirit of divination it was made evident to him that they expected co-operation, and retired for the want of it, I am at a lo≈øs to determine. If circum≈øtances at that time made it evident, tho≈øe circum≈øtances ≈øhould have been declared; or if ≈øub≈øequent events evinced it, every principle of common ju≈øtice, could they have influence upon the Colonel, ought to have impelled him to relate them, that no undue deductions might be drawn from what he ≈øaid in injury to a man by his means on trial for his reputation. It is not however from this in≈øtance alone that I am warranted to ≈øay that he is ≈øeldom explicit, but where he thinks what he ≈øays will condemn me; end throws in ≈øo dubious light every thing of a contrary tendency, that he appears to hope unfavourable inferences may be drawn from it. Certain it is, that until the arrival of the de≈øerter he ≈øpeaks of, which was after the Ea≈øt Florida troops had retreated, the ultimate end of their views appeared and was believed to be no more than an intention to ravage and lay wa≈øte as much of the State of Georgia as they could, to plunder the inhabitants and drive off the ≈øtock,‚Äîthe latter of much more importance to St. Augu≈øtine than people, unacquainted with its ≈øituation and the precariou≈øne≈øs of its ≈øupplies, would be apt to imagine. I confe≈øs that after-events demon≈øtrated plainly that co-operation was then expected, but as nothing previous exi≈øted to induce the idea, the Colonel ≈øhould have expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf in ≈øuch a manner as to have left no po≈ø≈øibility of implication that there did; and this I doubt not he would have done, had ju≈øtice been all that he aimed at. I however ≈øet at defiance the utmo≈øt ≈øtretch of his malice, either within the≈øe walls or without them. He tells you further, that this account given by the man of the tran≈øport was ≈øo much credited, that Doctor Hall and him≈øelf were ≈øent by the Governor and Council to Charle≈øtown to commune with General Lincoln (then either arrived or expected) upon the general ≈øituation of the State, and to give him the intelligence brought by the de≈øerter; that I was in South-Carolina when the≈øe advices were tran≈ømitted, and he takes it for granted I had them as early as others, but when or by whom he knows not, or what mea≈øures were taken in con≈øequence; that the time I arrived at Savanna he cannot preci≈øely a≈øcertain, but that it appeared I was not expected, as the Delegates lately arrived from Congre≈øs had reported I was recalled from the department, and General Lincoln was ordered on to ≈øupercede me. Come, however, he ≈øays I did, rea≈ø≈øumed the command, gave a≈ø≈øurances that I would defend the town, and that there was little danger. What the Colonel means by the greate≈øt part of this I am at a lo≈øs to determine. I think I may be pretty certain that he does not mean to ≈øerve me by it, and yet I cannot ≈øee how it can operate to injure me. It appears, in ≈øhort, altogether in≈øignificant as to any relative tendency until the latter end of it, when the cloven foot appears in the in≈øinuation that I gave improper encouragement to the inhabitants to ≈øtay in town, that I was not expected, and that the command was a≈ø≈øumed; that is, I ≈øuppo≈øe, though he does not ≈øpeak out, that having been recalled I had no bu≈øine≈øs there. If this be his meaning, I am amazed that a ≈øenior Colonel of a State and Commandant of militia had not, in the cour≈øe of ≈øervice, or by the dictates of common ≈øen≈øe, been taught, that though another General had been appointed to the department. I could not with military propriety leave it until his arrival, and that therefore I could not rea≈ø≈øume what had not been laid a≈øide.
